Award.AwardTitle: Interdisciplinary Workshop on the Development of a National Broadband Research Agenda

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Broadband Opportunity Council (BOC) defined its guiding principles as identifying and removing regulatory barriers to the deployment of broadband infrastructures, encouraging public and private investments in networks and services, promoting adoption and meaningful use of broadband, and accomplishing the above in ways that promote the public interest. To secure these principles the BOC, among other recommendations, called on agencies to 'improve data collection, analysis and research on broadband.'

This project includes organizing a workshop designed to promote a three-cornered dialog between policymakers, researchers and data managers (implementation agencies), to collectively define a broadband research agenda that will ultimately provide answers to questions relevant to each of these stakeholders. The organizers will seek to secure the participation of broadband experts from multiple stakeholders, including universities and university affiliated research institutes, regulatory agencies, policy makers, industry bodies, and implementation agencies. A publicly available workshop report will be created to disseminate workshop findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award supported two workshops (2016 and 2017) providing insights into the ways in which academic research can contribute to fostering a robust broadband infrastructure across the U.S. These efforts are embedded in a broader discourse, catalyzed by the White House in March 2015 in the form of the Broadband Opportunity Council. The council brought together representatives from various federal agencies to identify how, through their own programs and interactions with external stakeholders, these agencies could create synergies to promote development and use of broadband. The workshops engaged a critical stakeholder group – academics – to identify both the contributions of academics to broadband development through their research and, more importantly, to define priorities for future research.

As reflected in the report from our first workshop, Broadband 2021 (https://broadband.ist.psu.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2016/09/Broadband-2021_Final_Report.pdf), the academic research on broadband is highly interdisciplinary, spanning the fields of computer science, information science, communications, economics, sociology, and law, just to name a few. Importantly, participants at both workshops reflected this diversity, as well as geographic and racial/ethnic diversity, and diverse federal agencies, insuring a broad range of perspectives were represented in the discussions.

Our first workshop partitioned broadband research into three categories: technology, usage and impacts. The technology portion identified research questions associated with nine themes, spanning topics critical for enabling development of the next generation of broadband technologies, to special user groups whose needs are unmet by current technologies. Enabling development of future wireless technologies is dependent on access to spectrum. Understanding the effectiveness, and lack thereof, of these technologies can be bolstered by policies that make public data on the use of existing infrastructure. This is critical for identifying new technological trajectories. The perspectives of users also featured prominently in consideration of future broadband technologies. Issues of usability, technologies that enable the measurement of user experience, and addressing the needs of persons with disabilities and non-English speakers, particularly in emergency communications, were all identified as areas for future research.

In terms of usage, themes ranged from availability and use of new technologies, to policy environments, and significant issues for usage research. Participants, as reflected in the report, highlighted a variety of definitions of use, these fundamental metrics must advance with each generation of broadband, and the importance of equity in use. They also identified a need for more research policies in a range of environments beyond the national level, including international comparative analyses to inform our own national agenda, but also within tribal governments. Researchers of broadband use also highlighted the need for more interdisciplinary and multimethod research, as well as the need for sharing data.

Researchers also reflected on the effects of broadband for our economy, as well as social and individual well-being.   The themes span the nature of effects, how effects change with changing technologies, and mechanisms for supporting more effective research. In terms of the nature of effects, priority areas for research included understanding not only the benefits but the complementary factors that can enhance them. These include social and economic impacts, as well as effects on labor demand. Similar to those in the technology and uses tracks, these researchers also identified the need for data, whether through better collection mechanisms or sharing of existing data sets.

Unsurprisingly, given the common themes across the three domains, recommendations targeted the need for greater support of interdisciplinary research and data sharing. Interdisciplinary programs, funded by NSF or NSF in collaboration with other federal agencies, can help insure the continuation of broadband research, particularly given the influence of funding on faculty research priorities. A potential cost saver for this research, and one that aligns with the increasing emphasis on ‘open data,’ is data sharing between and among federal government agencies, the private sector, and academia.  

These themes were further elaborated in a panel held at the annual meeting of the Research Conference on Communications, Information and Internet Policy (TPRC) and a small workshop held at American University. The panelists included staff from NSF and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA). Together, the panel and follow up workshop amplified and provided more specific information on these outcomes. The federal agency panelists identified existing research programs, yet recognized the need for greater interdisciplinarity. Similarly, outcomes of the second workshop included recommendations for enhanced interactions and information flows between policymakers and academics. A summary of outcomes and recommendations, as well as two papers, appear in a special issue of the open access Journal of Information Policy (https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jinfopoli.8.issue-2018).
